I like the utility that a truck gives me, but I refuse to drive one that looks like every other one. My truck has only one person to please - me, and I have put my personal stamp on every one I have owned. I admit enjoying and appreciating the complements I receive, but mainly my truck is my toy. Current toy is an '04 Ford Ranger, one of six Fords, but I have owned Chebbys,Toyotas, Nissans, Mazdas and a Plymouth (yes, a Plymouth pickup) and they all gave me good service.

 I'm looking for a new tow vehicle for towing race cars. Since I need to pull ahead a lease on a Chrysler T&C, I'm leaning towards either a hemi Durango or hemi Dodge Ram. If I didn't have the need to dump the T&C, I'd probably go with a Ford Super Duty w/turbo diesel.

I'm looking for a new tow vehicle for towing race cars. Since I need to pull ahead a lease on a Chrysler T&C, I'm leaning towards either a hemi Durango or hemi Dodge Ram. If I didn't have the need to dump the T&C, I'd probably go with a Ford Super Duty w/turbo diesel.

 
 Don't fool around with the gas engines, get the turbo diesel and forget about it and any towing limitations for at least 250k miles. Resale is also spectacular when compared to gas engined vehicles. Financially, if you intend to keep the tow vehicle for any period of time, you'd be way ahead of the game by taking the lease early termination hit now and buying the new vehicle.

 I looked at all the diesel powered domestics in 3/4 and 1T auto trans configurations. Dodge had by far the highest transmission and differential failure rate of all three. A diesel repair shop told me that their opinion on the high failure rate was the Cummings torque rate, 500ft lb, compared to 400 ft lb on the others, being mated to drivetrains not adequately engineered for that torque. they also stated that for Dodge to re-engineer the drive train would put Dodge in a higher retail cost bracket and Cummings won't drop it because that goes in their general product line applications. Dodge's largest diesel pickup market sector is retired folks towing big trailers, RV advocates, who are very cost conscious. I have zero domestic brand loyalty and decided what most of the ranchers and farmers around here drive, Ford diesels, was also a pretty good testimonial. I won't be towing anything heavier than a car hauler, not while there are still 4-5 star hotels with room service, so towing capacity to handle a small home wasn't a consideration.

I rather have a small block. They last longer.

 
 Not in modified form. Especially at street friendly levels; much easier to get reliable 500hp from big blocks, 454 and 460 with less of an aggressive cam profile and lower C/R, than small blocks. I have both after fooling with small blocks many years ago. Small block for the street is fine up to about 2500lbs, but above that the effort to produce HP is much higher than with cubic inches. 
 
 But, some people prefer one and some the other. To each his/her own.

Not in modified form. Especially at street friendly levels; much easier to get reliable 500hp from big blocks, 454 and 460 with less of an aggressive cam profile and lower C/R, than small blocks.  My 396 small block motor was built 6 years ago, has run mid 11's naturally aspirated and now 10's with nitrous. My car weighs almost 3600 pounds and still runs like a clock. If you have good components, a small block can be made to run forever. Callies crank, Manley forged rods, billet main caps and JE pistons, very aggressive cam. 
 I agree that its easier to get 500HP from a big block, but they don't fit well into a relatively stock bodied 94Z28.

As far as small blocks go, I know of multiple people running low 12s in 3800+lbs thunderbirds with a "tiny" 281cid motor, naturally aspirated and on pump gas.
 
 The only reason for a big block is towing/hauling.

As far as small blocks go, I know of multiple people running low 12s in 3800+lbs thunderbirds with a "tiny" 281cid motor, naturally aspirated and on pump gas.
 
 The only reason for a big block is towing/hauling.

 
 Unless, like myself, one likes a torque curve that delivers desired power at much lower RPMS for 5000lb+ vehicles.

As far as small blocks go, I know of multiple people running low 12s in 3800+lbs thunderbirds with a "tiny" 281cid motor, naturally aspirated and on pump gas.
 
 The only reason for a big block is towing/hauling.

 There is an old saying, "There is no substitute for cubic inches". When I started hot-rodding, that was the way to get performance. When I stuffed a 400 inch Olds in my '50 Chebby, we considered 1HP per cubic inch an accomplishment. Nowadays builders are getting much more than that and small blocks are powerful and very quick, but the old axiom remains true,
 Dono

There is an old saying, "There is no substitute for cubic inches". When I started hot-rodding, that was the way to get performance. When I stuffed a 400 inch Olds in my '50 Chebby, we considered 1HP per cubic inch an accomplishment. Nowadays builders are getting much more than that and small blocks are powerful and very quick, but the old axiom remains true,
 Dono

 
 My first was what was known as a 3/8 x 3/8 flathead in a '40 Ford Coupe. That was, with three Stromberg 97s and all the rest, about as radical as a street flathead could get. 239CI plus the overbore. It would take most anything stock on the streets until 1957. Detroit then climbed on the performance wagon and by the early '60s cubic inches, 400+, dominated streets, strips and circle tracks. It still holds true in the unlimited classes of drag racing, only 600ci+ is the standard. To me, a small block V8 doesn't have another, again to me, very important factor, that deep sound of a big block with a 230-degree cam, headers and 3" dump tubes that at 800rmp ragged idle will set off every car alarm within 100-yards. With some things, size does make a difference.

There is an old saying, "There is no substitute for cubic inches". When I started hot-rodding, that was the way to get performance. When I stuffed a 400 inch Olds in my '50 Chebby, we considered 1HP per cubic inch an accomplishment. Nowadays builders are getting much more than that and small blocks are powerful and very quick, but the old axiom remains true,
 Dono
High CIDs are good for providing plenty of pullin' power over a wide range of rpm. The Indy cars, Nascar and some fast dragsters use smaller engines turning close to or just above 10 grand. Some of the better engines in F1 run close to 20! You just can't do that with big pistons. That's why the V-12s don't have as much displacement as the big V-8s.

There is an old saying, "There is no substitute for cubic inches". When I started hot-rodding, that was the way to get performance. When I stuffed a 400 inch Olds in my '50 Chebby, we considered 1HP per cubic inch an accomplishment. Nowadays builders are getting much more than that and small blocks are powerful and very quick, but the old axiom remains true,
 Dono

 
 We're in the process of finishing the installation of a twin turbo LS-1 in my son's 94Z28. It'll make over 1000 RWHP with 350CI. That's ~3HP/CI and it'll be perfectly streetable. Boost equalizes the playing field between big block and small block. emoticon_cool

 My 396 stroked LT-1 (SBC) dumps to a single 4" exhaust and has heads turning and thumbs up from people that I pass by. At the Woodward Dreamcruise, I hooked up dual purge lines and had the car snorting nitrous while doing massive burnouts. I went through a 10 pound bottle of nitrous just fooling around with the crowds. My buddy wore down half of his $400/each tires in his 85 supercharged Lingenfelter Vette, but the crowd still preferred the nitrous line purging. If you've never been to Michigan for THE CRUISE, you don't know what you're missing. emoticon_cool

 I agree totally. I have been a motorhead for over 50 years and marvel at the advances in performance I have seen. While I did ride a nitro Harley stroker in one event (big thrill), all my drag experience was in the 40 inch (650cc)class motorcycles. My Triumph and BSA motorcycles were full race(gas) and today a stocker right off the showroom floor with less displacement is much quicker than mine ever were. Today dragsters are posting higher speeds in the quarter mile than the world land speed record of my time.... and the race goes on.
 Dono

If you like rumbling and smells that much, you should come to a monster truck show at the Georgia Dome. The sound is deafening and you can feel your clothes vibrating.
 
 That's not really in my bag of favorite engine worship though. I prefer Unlimited Late Model Dirt cars on a track that doesn't require the Borla mufflers. Sometimes it's a thrill just to listen to a big motor idle while waiting to qualify...but when you get 24 cars snortin' into turn one on the first lap, it blows angel dust on the sensory perceptors.
 
 You're right about the smell of nitromethane, too. Some of the winged sprint car races have really irritated my eyes, but the nose is in heaven!

Ever heard of gears? A smaller, higher revving engine could put down the same torque at the wheels, make more power, and get better mileage. 
 
 A lower torque peak isn't better, it shows the inefficiency of the engine.
...like the 40hp '58 Volkswagen that could beat the '57 Chevy across the intersection...only to lose the race within a block!
 
 Gearing is extremely important in mechanical drives. Gearing is how engineers manage to spin an entire restuarant with a quarter horsepower electric motor.
 
 However, there's much to be said for low-end torque whereby you can just barely touch the throttle of a good diesel engine hooked to a decent torque converter and feel the whole load advance like you'd stomped on the gas pedal of a light sedan. Georged pegged it on that thought! Those that tow are in the know!

If you like rumbling and smells that much, you should come to a monster truck show at the Georgia Dome. The sound is deafening and you can feel your clothes vibrating.

 The first monster truck and tractor pull that I ever atended was in the Spectrum in Philly back in the late 70's IIRC. (The Spectrum is where the 76ers played basketball. It's way smaller than a football field.) Art Arfon had his Sikorsky jet powered beer can tractor cranked up so high that the suspended scoreboard began to oscillate from the exhaust (vented straight up). Balloons, dust and all sorts of trash got caught in the convection currents produced and XXXX rained down for 1/2 an hour. You want to talk about loud. Imagine a jet on a bball court. emoticon_wow emoticon_wow 
 

 That's not really in my bag of favorite engine worship though. I prefer Unlimited Late Model Dirt cars on a track that doesn't require the Borla mufflers. Sometimes it's a thrill just to listen to a big motor idle while waiting to qualify...but when you get 24 cars snortin' into turn one on the first lap, it blows angel dust on the sensory perceptors.

 Never could quite get the concept of racing around in circles for hours. I'd get dizzy. I'm strictly a straight line racer. :) 
 

 You're right about the smell of nitromethane, too. Some of the winged sprint car races have really irritated my eyes, but the nose is in heaven!

 Better than the smel of starting ether. :)

...like the 40hp '58 Volkswagen that could beat the '57 Chevy across the intersection...only to lose the race within a block!
 
 Gearing is extremely important in mechanical drives. Gearing is how engineers manage to spin an entire restuarant with a quarter horsepower electric motor.
 
 However, there's much to be said for low-end torque whereby you can just barely touch the throttle of a good diesel engine hooked to a decent torque converter and feel the whole load advance like you'd stomped on the gas pedal of a light sedan. Georged pegged it on that thought! Those that tow are in the know!

 
 Nah, torque is when you rev a 1000HP motor up with your finger on the transbrake and let go. The torque convertors 2.5 multiplication factor sends 2500 pounds of torque through the driveline in an instant and you look out the windshield and see nothing but blue sky for 100' til the front wheels touch back down. That's nirvana. :)

...
 
 Never could quite get the concept of racing around in circles for hours. I'd get dizzy. I'm strictly a straight line racer. :) 
 
 ...
Circle racing is about preparedness, stamina, skill and luck. It takes all of those to be in the front after 100 laps or so. The excitement of watching several cars negotiate banked corners with all of them in a four wheel drift, just inches apart (if they manage to stay apart), throwing dirt-and-rubber twin rooster tails and the anxiety associated with hoping your favorite driver's engine and drive train will stay together that makes dirt track racing a magnet for me.
 
 There's quite much in the way of preparation and car set-up that will make or break a run for the front spot, even in an 8 lap heat race. It's far more complicated than drag racing. You're competing with other drivers all the time, not just trying to be consistent with elapsed times.
 
 Don't get me wrong...I like drag races, too. I had a friend in high school who was ape over it...had a fire engine red '56 Chevy tudor no-poster and was really good at engine work. Back then, it was a great accomplishment to home-build an engine that would turn 7000rpm and stay together. Baroni was good at it.

... 
 
 Better than the smell of starting ether. :)
LOL! I keep a can in my truck just in case I need to snort a bit every now and then! emoticon_xclown
 
 Even the smell of kerosene and diesel fuel will make my nostrils flare for more...better than the smell of fryin' bacon!

 Don't get me wrong...I like drag races, too. I had a friend in high school who was ape over it...had a fire engine red '56 Chevy tudor no-poster and was really good at engine work. Back then, it was a great accomplishment to home-build an engine that would turn 7000rpm and stay together. Baroni was good at it.

 
 Don't get me wrong, I admire the engineering that goes into roundy-round cars and engines. For instance, knowing how to keep a 700HP engine alive for 500 miles straight at over 8000 rpms average is truly impressive feat that's accomplished at every NASCAR race. 
 I just don't happen to get my kicks out of running around in circles or watching others do the same. emoticon_frazzled

 You truly are a "MOTORHEAD". Congrats! :)

 I just don't happen to get my kicks out of running around in circles or watching others do the same. emoticon_frazzled

 It's just easier to run in circles than it is to find tracks 100 miles long where you can see the whole race without watching it on TV!
 
 ...and dirt track racing is several orders of magnitude better than Nascar!

It's just easier to run in circles than it is to find tracks 100 miles long where you can see the whole race without watching it on TV!
 
 ...and dirt track racing is several orders of magnitude better than Nascar!

 I think racing is a basic instinct in man. Be it drags, dirt tracks or big ovals, they all serve their purpose. I recall racing forklifts in a large warehouse, I still hold the track record.
 Dono

It's just easier to run in circles than it is to find tracks 100 miles long where you can see the whole race without watching it on TV!
 

 
 Salt Flats would be fun.
 

 ...and dirt track racing is several orders of magnitude better than Nascar!

 
 Yeah, you get to wipe dirt off your teeth. :)

When I was in college, it was fun to bet on the lawn mower races. That was in the '60s.
 
 Now I have a friend who actually races suped-up lawn mowers. They have sponsors and travel around the country racing riding lawn mowers...that will top 50mph!

When I was in college, it was fun to bet on the lawn mower races. That was in the '60s.
 
 Now I have a friend who actually races suped-up lawn mowers. They have sponsors and travel around the country racing riding lawn mowers...that will top 50mph!

 
 The only races I bet on are between horses. To watch one carrying my money come from out of the money in the home stretch and take the wire beats any motorized race.

The only races I bet on are between horses. To watch one carrying my money come from out of the money in the home stretch and take the wire beats any motorized race.
If you ever get near Prestonsburg, Kentucky when there's a dirt race going on, you should try it. They have the dirt track inside the horse track...a full bar...good concessions...betting windows that allow you to bet on every horse race in the USA 'til the California tracks close...and you can mozie out to the grandstands with your drink in hand to watch a few laps of DLM racing!

If you ever get near Prestonsburg, Kentucky when there's a dirt race going on, you should try it. They have the dirt track inside the horse track...a full bar...good concessions...betting windows that allow you to bet on every horse race in the USA 'til the California tracks close...and you can mozie out to the grandstands with your drink in hand to watch a few laps of DLM racing!

 
 I only bet on horses when I can view them in the paddock and then watch them run. Did attend the '83 Kentucky Derby, a party to end all parties even with that miserable humidity.
 
 I like dirt track auto racing. My preferences are road racing and then short circle track (dirt or asphalt). I participated in drag racing years ago and eventually found it boring as money and professional engine builders began to dominate all classes. I like building my own but checkbooks are the current standard. I find NASCAR circle track as boring as football or baseball but endless repetition is what the masses seem to prefer in their hero worship.

I only bet on horses when I can view them in the paddock and then watch them run. Did attend the '83 Kentucky Derby, a party to end all parties even with that miserable humidity.
 
 I like dirt track auto racing. My preferences are road racing and then short circle track (dirt or asphalt). I participated in drag racing years ago and eventually found it boring as money and professional engine builders began to dominate all classes. I like building my own but checkbooks are the current standard. I find NASCAR circle track as boring as football or baseball but endless repetition is what the masses seem to prefer in their hero worship.
I've not made it to the Derby yet. I used to watch it every year with my mom.
 
 Nascar has turned sour since David Pearson, Richard Petty, the Allison's, Cale Yarborough, Marvin Panch, Tiny Lund and several other GREAT drivers got out of it. It's all about marketing now. I seldom watch the restrictor plate (Daytona, Talladega) races except for the last few laps.
 
 And you're definitely right about speed costing money. A couple of years ago it was said that in order to run a Nascar team for one year you need about 7 million dollars...8 if you wanted to win!
 
 Some of the dirt racing sanctioning bodies are trying to stem that trend by creating the "spec" motor and "crate" motor classes, but the response of the fans has not been as good as expected...we like the fa$t cars!

Nascar has turned sour since David Pearson, Richard Petty, the Allison's, Cale Yarborough, Marvin Panch, Tiny Lund and several other GREAT drivers got out of it. It's all about marketing now. I seldom watch the restrictor plate (Daytona, Talladega) races except for the last few laps.

 
 Definitely big, big business. A long way from my memories of being able to chat with Petty and others in the pits like it was a local race track. The cars looked like what was available on showroom floors and you could bring your own beer! Those days are forever gone.

Definitely big, big business. A long way from my memories of being able to chat with Petty and others in the pits like it was a local race track. The cars looked like what was available on showroom floors and you could bring your own beer! Those days are forever gone.

 
 That's another thing that I like about drag racing. You can still walk into the pits and chat with the top drivers. emoticon_cool
